header.title: Welcome to Clipposaurus
header.description: Clipposaurus is your instant, zero-signup, open-source digital clipboard with true end-to-end encryption. Share text and code across any device in seconds by creating a Drop. Your Drop lives for up to 1 hour — then it's automatically and permanently erased. We can't see your content, track you, or recover anything later. Privacy isn't a feature here — it's the foundation.

sections.title: Create a Drop
sections.description: Follow these simple steps to create a Drop to share text or code snippets using Clipposaurus.

data.title: Step 1: Visit Clipposaurus
items: Go to **clipposaurus.com** in any modern browser — desktop or mobile. No login, no app download, and nothing to install.

data.title: Step 2: Click “Create Drop”
items: Press the **Create Drop** button on the homepage.
This opens the secure editor where you'll add your content.

data.title: Step 3: Add Your Content
items: **Text** — type or paste anything. Unlimited characters, formatting preserved.
**Code** — paste a snippet. Auto-highlighting detects 20+ languages.
You can add one type or mix all three in the same Drop.

data.title: Step 4: Set Your Drop Key
items: Create your Drop Key by choosing the third word (the user secret). Use any letters, numbers, or symbols (6-8 characters).
Clipposaurus generates the first and second words automatically (the identifier and system secret).
Together they form a simple, memorable key like **apple-beer-ocean**.
Only the full key unlocks your Drop — we never store or see it.

data.title: Step 5: Choose How Long It Lives
items: Pick a retention period: **Delete after first access** (max access time 1 hour), **30 minutes** or **1 hour**.
Your Drop deletes automatically based on your choice — nothing remains afterward.

data.title: Step 6: Create & Save Your Drop
items: Click **Create My Drop**.
Your content is encrypted locally in your browser before uploading — Clipposaurus never sees it.
Copy or save your final Drop Key (e.g., **apple-beer-ocean**). It's the ONLY way to access your Drop.

sections.title: Open a Drop
sections.description: Use a Drop Key to securely open a Drop and access shared content.

data.title: Step 1: Visit Clipposaurus
items: Open **clipposaurus.com** in any modern browser.
Click **Open Drop** on the homepage.

data.title: Step 2: Enter the Drop Key
items: Type the full Drop Key (e.g., **apple-beer-ocean**).
The first word (identifier) finds the encrypted Drop.
The full Drop Key decrypts it — on your device only.

data.title: Step 3: Get Access to Your Content
items: Your content decrypts instantly in your browser — never on our servers.
Copy text or code
If the Drop was set to “delete after access,” it will be erased immediately. Otherwise, it remains available until the retention time expires.

header.title: A Deep Dive into Clipposaurus Architecture
header.description: Clipposaurus is built on a true zero-knowledge foundation: your content is encrypted on your device, stored only in encrypted form, and deleted automatically. This page explains the complete high-level flow of how a drop is created, stored, accessed, and destroyed.

data.heading: Your Browser Is the Runtime
data.text: Clipposaurus doesn't use backend rendering, preprocessing, or content inspection. Everything—from text editing to code highlighting runs inside the browser using Web APIs.

data.heading: Nothing Leaves Your Device Until You Decide
data.text: As long as you're creating or editing content, no network requests are made at all. The Network tab in DevTools stays empty until the moment you choose to create a drop.

data.heading: No Identity Layer
data.text: There are no accounts, cookies, analytics, or unique identifiers. Each session is a clean, anonymous environment that resets every time you load the page.

sections.title: You Create a Drop Key
sections.description: A drop key is composed of three human-readable words. The first word is called the identifier and tells Clipposaurus which encrypted blob to retrieve. The complete Drop Key unlocks it locally on your device using — ensuring that only someone with the full drop key can ever decrypt the content.

data.label: Identifier
data.content: Randomly generated by Clipposaurus (e.g., “apple”). This word becomes the lookup index for the encrypted blob stored on the server.

data.label: System Secret
data.content: This word is generated automatically similar to the identifier but is never shared with or stored by the server (e.g., beer). This word adds a critical layer of entropy to the Drop Key, making it vastly more difficult to guess or brute-force.

data.label: User Secret
data.content: Choose this word yourself. It stays on your device and is never sent to our servers (for example, 'ocean'). Without it, the encrypted content cannot be decrypted. For best security, make it 6-8 characters long. For highly sensitive content, use a mix of letters, special characters, and numbers.

sections.title: Client-Side Encryption
sections.description: Before any creating Drop, Clipposaurus derives a strong cryptographic key from the full drop key and encrypts your content locally using AES-256-GCM.

data.title: Key Derivation
data.text: Your complete drop key is fed into PBKDF2 using a secure number of iterations, producing a 256-bit key.

data.title: Local Encryption
data.text: Text and code are encrypted inside your browser. Metadata, formatting, and content are all sealed inside the ciphertext.

data.title: Upload
data.text: Only the encrypted blob is sent to the server. The plaintext content and your secret word are never transmitted.

sections.title: Storage: Only Ciphertext
sections.description: The server stores a single object: the encrypted blob, indexed by the public identifier. No part of the drop key, no metadata, and no content details are visible.

items: No knowledge of text or code content
No versioning or shadow storage
No pattern recognition or scanning possible

sections.title: Access = Local Decryption
sections.description: When someone enters the full drop key, Clipposaurus retrieves the encrypted blob and decrypts it directly in the browser. At no point does the server see, process, or reconstruct the decrypted content.

items: User enters Drop Key
Server locates blob using first word (identifier)
Encrypted blob is downloaded
Browser derives key using the secret word
Content is decrypted locally using WebCrypto

sections.title: Automatic Expiration & Destruction
sections.description: Every drop has a strict retention policy. Once the timer expires—or the drop is accessed one time if configured—the encrypted blob is permanently deleted.

items: No backups or mirrored copies
No versioning or shadow storage
No recovery possible after expiration

header.title: The Key to Absolute Privacy.
header.description: Clipposaurus uses a three-word Drop Key for stronger protection against guessing, brute-forcing, and pattern-based attacks. Each part has a different role and only the complete Drop Key — identifier, system secret, and user secret — can decrypt your content.

sections.title: Identifier (1st Word)
sections.description: The first word is generated randomly and is the only part of the key visible to the server. It acts solely as a locator for your encrypted drop.

data.name: Identifier
can: Locate your encrypted blob on our servers.
Be stored in plain form without exposing secrets.
cannot: Decrypt or reveal any part of your content.
Expose or hint at the system secret or user secret.
Be used to guess the rest of your drop key.

sections.title: System Secret (2nd Word)
sections.description: The second word is generated automatically similar to the identifier but is never shared with or stored by the server. This word adds a critical layer of entropy to the drop key, making it vastly more difficult to guess or brute-force.

data.name: System Secret
can: Protect against guessing attacks on user secrets
cannot: Store or retrieved by the server.
Be used alone to decrypt content.

sections.title: User Secret (3rd Word)
sections.description: The third word is chosen entirely by the user and must be 6-8 characters long. This forms the private part of the key known only to the user and device.

data.name: User Secret
can: Be chosen by yourself for memorability and more randomness.
Be any combination of letters, numbers, or symbols within 6-8 characters.
Be memorized or stored securely by the user.
Provide the final layer of security for decryption.
cannot: Store or retrieved by the server.
Be used alone to decrypt content.

sections.title: The Complete Drop Key
sections.description: When the three words are combined with hyphens (example: 'apple-beer-ocean'), they form your complete Drop Key. This triplet is required to derive the encryption key using PBKDF2.

items: The combined drop key is processed through PBKDF2 on your device to produce a strong 256-bit AES-GCM encryption key. This ensures encryption is done entirely locally and never on our servers.
Even if an attacker knows the identifier, the system secret and user secret dramatically increase entropy, making it practically impossible to brute-force or predict the full key.
Each word contributes independently to the overall strength: the identifier helps locate the drop, the system secret adds random cryptographic strength, and the user secret adds personalized entropy.
If any one of the three words is lost, the drop becomes permanently inaccessible. This ensures that only someone with the complete triplet can decrypt the content, protecting your privacy.

The format balances memorability and security: the identifier and system secret are pronounceable, making sharing easier while maintaining cryptographic strength. The user secret is completely your choice—you can make it memorable for easy access or more complex for enhanced security.

sections.title: Sharing Your Drop Key Securely
sections.description: Anyone with the complete three-word drop key can unlock your drop and access your content. Choose secure communication channels and consider the sensitivity of your shared data when deciding how to transmit the key.

header.title: End-to-End Encryption You Can Trust
header.description: Clipposaurus uses modern, battle-tested cryptography. Your browser derives keys, encrypts your content, and decrypts it locally. Our servers only ever see encrypted data — never your plaintext, drop key, or AES keys.

sections.title: Key Derivation with PBKDF2
sections.description: Your human-friendly Drop Key (like `apple-beer-ocean`) is great for people, but too weak and structured for cryptography. We need to turn it into a long, unpredictable, machine-strength key. That's where PBKDF2 comes in.

whatIs.title: What is PBKDF2?
items: PBKDF2 (Password-Based Key Derivation Function 2) is a standard way to turn a password or phrase into a strong cryptographic key. It doesn't just hash your password once; it runs it through a hash function many times with a unique salt.

In Clipposaurus, your Drop Key is fed into PBKDF2 with SHA-256, along with a unique salt generated for each drop. PBKDF2 is configured with a high number of iterations (e.g. 100,000+), which makes each guessing attempt computationally expensive.

howWeUseIt.title: How Clipposaurus Uses PBKDF2?
items: We combine the three words of your drop key into a single secret input.
We generate a random salt for each drop so that even identical keys produce completely different derived keys.
We run PBKDF2 with SHA-256 and a large iteration count (100,000+), which stretches the key and slows down brute-force attempts.
The output is a 256-bit key suitable for AES-256-GCM.

items.label: Brute-force resistance
items.text: PBKDF2 makes every guessing attempt computationally expensive, preventing attackers from trying millions of keys per second.

items.label: Unique Encryption Keys
items.text: Each drop generates a unique encryption key through the use of random salts, ensuring that even drops with similar inputs produce completely different encrypted results.

items.label: No raw passwords
items.text: Your three-word key is never used directly. PBKDF2 transforms it into a high-entropy, fixed-length key suitable for AES-256.

sections.title: AES-256-GCM Encryption
sections.description: Once PBKDF2 finishes, we have a strong 256-bit key. That key is used with AES-256-GCM — a modern, widely trusted encryption mode.

whatIs.title: What is AES-256-GCM?
items: AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a symmetric encryption algorithm used globally by governments, banks, and security-sensitive applications. The '256' means it uses a 256-bit key, which is considered secure against brute-force attacks with current and foreseeable hardware.

GCM (Galois/Counter Mode) is a mode of operation for AES that provides both confidentiality (hiding the content) and integrity (detecting tampering). This combination is often called 'authenticated encryption'.

howWeUseIt.title: How AES-256-GCM Works in Practice?
items: Your browser generates a random IV/nonce for each encryption operation. Reusing IVs is dangerous; we always use fresh values.
Your content (text or code) is encrypted with AES-256 using the derived key plus the IV.
GCM also produces an authentication tag. When someone later decrypts the content, this tag is checked to ensure the ciphertext hasn't been altered.
If any bit of the encrypted data or tag is modified, decryption fails — preventing silent corruption or tampering.

whyItMatters.title: Why AES-256-GCM is a Good Fit for Clipposaurus?

items.label: Strong security
items.text: AES-256 is a widely trusted encryption standard used by governments and organizations worldwide, providing robust protection against brute-force attacks.

items.label: Tamper detection
items.text: You're protected not just from eavesdropping but also from undetected content modification.

items.label: Performance
items.text: Modern browsers use hardware acceleration for AES-GCM, so encryption and decryption stay fast even for larger payloads.

items.label: Compatibility
items.text: AES-GCM is well-supported by the Web Crypto API, which means the logic runs natively in your browser, not on our servers.

sections.title: Local-Only Encryption
sections.description: All of this happens entirely inside your browser before anything touches the network. Only encrypted blobs ever leave your device, and without your Drop Key, those blobs are cryptographically useless.

flow.title: Encryption Flow
items: You enter or paste your content (text or code). Nothing is sent yet.
You provide or confirm your three-word drop key.
PBKDF2 runs in your browser to derive a 256-bit key from your drop key + salt.
AES-256-GCM encrypts your content locally, producing ciphertext + authentication tag.
Only the encrypted blob, public identifier, and retention settings are sent to Clipposaurus servers.

weReceive.title: What we receive
items: Encrypted content (ciphertext + auth tag)
The identifier (first word of your Drop Key)
Retention/expiration configuration

weNeverReceive.title: What we NEVER receive
items: Your Drop Key
Your PBKDF2-derived AES key
Your plaintext content
Your system secret or user secret words

sections.title: Local-Only Decryption
sections.description: Decryption is simply the same process in reverse — and it also happens entirely inside the browser of whoever has the Drop Key. The servers never see the decrypted content or the full Drop Key. The only place your data exists in readable form is on the devices of people who know the full Drop Key.

flow.title: Decryption Flow
items: The user visits Clipposaurus and enters the full three-word Drop Key.
The identifier (word 1) is used to locate the encrypted blob on our servers.
The encrypted data is downloaded to the browser — still encrypted.
PBKDF2 runs again in the browser with the same Drop Key + stored salt to derive the same AES-256 key.
AES-256-GCM uses that key, plus the original IV and authentication tag, to decrypt the content and verify integrity.
If the Drop Key is wrong or the data has been tampered with, decryption fails and the content is not shown.

header.title: We CAN'T See Your Data — By Design
header.description: Clipposaurus is engineered so that your data is never exposed to us at any stage. Your device encrypts everything locally, and what reaches our servers is unusable without your drop key — which we never receive.

sections.title: What Zero-Knowledge Means
sections.description: Zero-knowledge architecture is a design principle where the service provider cannot access, reconstruct, or infer your content — even if they wanted to. Clipposaurus follows this principle at every layer.

data.label: We Never See Your Plaintext
data.text: Your device encrypts everything locally before it is sent. Clipposaurus servers never receive readable text or code.

data.label: We Never See Your Secret Key
data.text: Your three-word drop key is used only inside your browser to generate the actual encryption key. We never learn any part of it.

data.label: We Store Only Useless Noise
data.text: The encrypted blob stored on our servers is mathematically impossible to reverse without your key — which we never have.

sections.title: Why Zero-Knowledge Matters
sections.description: Our architecture gives you real, technical privacy — not policy-based promises.

data.label: Server Breaches Are Harmless
data.text: Even if an attacker stole every encrypted blob, they would only have unreadable noise without your Drop Key.

data.label: Legal Requests Produce Nothing
data.text: We cannot hand over your plaintext, because we never see it. We can only provide encrypted blobs — which are useless without your key.

data.label: Your Secrets Never Leave Your Device
data.text: Your browser handles key creation, encryption, and decryption entirely on your device through WebCrypto APIs.

data.label: No Backdoors, No Exceptions
data.text: There is no mechanism for us to decrypt your data. Even we must follow the exact same access rules as every other user.

sections.title: What We Store (and What We Don't)
sections.description: Our servers only hold the minimum information needed to temporarily keep your encrypted content available.

items.label: Encrypted Blob
items.text: This is your content after it has been fully scrambled by your browser. We cannot turn it back into readable text or code.

items.label: Identifier
items.text: A harmless first word of your drop key used only to locate your encrypted blob. It reveals nothing about your secret key.

items.label: Expiration Time
items.text: A simple timestamp that tells us when to delete your encrypted content forever.

items.label: Any Personal Data
items.text: No accounts, emails, names, IP logs, or anything tied to your identity.

items.label: Tracking Metadata
items.text: No analytics, fingerprinting, cookies, or behavioral data.

items.label: Password or Keys
items.text: Your complete Drop Key and AES key never reach our servers. They stay inside your browser.

sections.title: You Can Verify This Yourself
sections.description: Zero-knowledge is not something you are asked to trust — you can observe it directly.

data.label: Open Source Transparency
data.text: Our entire codebase is open source, allowing you to inspect the encryption and zero-knowledge implementation directly on GitHub.

data.label: Inspect Network Traffic
data.text: Open your browser's developer tools. You will see only encrypted blobs being uploaded — never your actual content or key.

data.label: Check Local Encryption
data.text: All encryption is done using the built-in WebCrypto API in your browser. No data is processed on our servers.

data.label: Verify Key Isolation
data.text: Your drop key never appears in any network request. It stays inside the browser's memory during the session.

header.title: Short-Lived by Design
header.description: Clipposaurus is intentionally ephemeral. Your encrypted drop exists only for a short window — and once it disappears, it is gone forever with no way to recover it. This minimizes the exposure of your sensitive content and ensures there is never a long-term copy stored anywhere.

sections.title: Retention Options
sections.description: When you create a drop, you control its lifespan. A shorter lifespan means a smaller window for anyone to attempt unauthorized access.

data.label: Delete After First Access
data.text: Ideal for sharing passwords or one-time secrets. Once someone opens the drop, it is instantly removed. The drop is kept for a maximum of 1 hour, during which it should be unlocked and the content accessed. Otherwise, after 1 hour, the drop is deleted even if no one has accessed it.

data.label: 30 Minutes
data.text: Good for quick collaboration or temporary sharing. Enough time for someone to open it once or twice.

data.label: 1 Hour
data.text: For situations where the receiver might not be available immediately. Still intentionally short to maintain privacy.

sections.title: Time-To-Live (TTL) Enforcement
sections.description: Expiration is not dependent on user actions. The system enforces deletion automatically, even if the drop is never accessed.

data.label: Database TTL
data.text: Every drop is inserted with an automatic expiration timer. Once the timer runs out, the database itself removes the encrypted blob.

data.label: Background Cleanup Jobs
data.text: Periodic tasks run on the backend to detect expired items and forcefully remove any lingering data.

data.label: Provider-Level Deletion
data.text: Storage partners (such as hosted databases) apply their own TTL or purge mechanisms, adding a second layer of enforcement.

sections.title: No Backups — Ever
sections.description: Traditional online platforms keep backups, replicas, snapshots, and audit logs that can indirectly store your data for months or years. Clipposaurus does not do this.

items.label: Redundant Copies
items.text: No mirrored backups or secondary storage locations.

items.label: Server Logs Referencing Your Drop
items.text: Logs never contain identifiers tied to your content.

items.label: Cached Unexpired Data
items.text: CDN servers have caching disabled for drops; no ghost copies exist.

items.label: Version History
items.text: Drops are not versioned and there is never an earlier copy preserved anywhere.

data.analogy: If Drop is deleted or expires, it is not recoverable by us.

items: Visit **clipposaurus.com** in any modern browser and click **Create Drop**. No downloads, installations, or accounts required - just open the website and you're ready to start sharing instantly.
Click the **Text** tab to access the text editor. This specialized mode is optimized for written content with unlimited character support and real-time formatting preview.

data.title: Step 2: Add Your Content
items: Type or paste any text content directly into the editor. Everything from quick notes to full documents is supported with no character limitations whatsoever.
Formatting is automatically preserved including line breaks, indentation, and special characters. Unicode support means content in any language displays perfectly.

data.title: Step 3: Generate Drop Key
items: The system generates the first two words (identifier and system secret) for you. You need to enter the user secret, which can be up to 6-8 characters. For easy recall, choose a memorable word; for better security, use a mix of letters, special characters, and numbers.
Now you have a Drop Key, for example: apple-beer-ocean. Please save or memorize this key. If you forget it, you cannot access your content anymore.

data.title: Step 4: Set Expiration
items: Choose your content retention period: delete after first access(kept for maximum 1 hour), 30 minutes, or 1 hour. These automatic deletion settings provide built-in privacy protection.
Consider who needs access and when. Delete-after-access works great for one-time sharing, while timed deletion is perfect for temporary collaboration.

data.title: Step 5: Create Your Drop
items: Click **'Create My Drop'** to encrypt and upload your content.
Your content is encrypted locally using AES-256-GCM before transmission. Our servers only receive encrypted data - we never see your original text.

data.title: Step 6: Share Securely
items: Copy your Drop Key and share it through secure channels. The key format is human-friendly like 'apple-beer-ocean' for easy verbal sharing or secure messaging.
Recipients can access your content by entering the drop key on any device. The decryption happens locally in their browser, maintaining end-to-end security.

data.title: Step 1: Select Code Mode
items: Visit **clipposaurus.com** in any modern browser and click **Create Drop**. No downloads, installations, or accounts required - just open the website and you're ready to start sharing instantly.

Click the **Code** tab to access the code editor. The code editor automatically detects your programming language or you can manually select from 20+ supported languages including JavaScript, Python, Java, C++, and more.

data.title: Step 2: Add Your Code
items: Paste or type your code directly into the editor. Everything from single-line commands to entire code snippets is supported with no character limitations.
Watch real-time syntax highlighting as you type. The editor preserves all formatting, indentation, and special characters perfectly while providing a beautiful coding experience.

data.title: Step 3: Choose Language
items: Select the correct programming language if auto-detection didn't work perfectly. This ensures optimal syntax highlighting and proper code formatting.

data.title: Step 4: Generate Drop Key
items: The system generates the first two words (identifier and system secret) for you. You need to enter the user secret, which can be up to 6-8 characters. For easy recall, choose a memorable word; for better security, use a mix of letters, special characters, and numbers.
Now you have a Drop Key, for example: apple-beer-ocean. Please save or memorize this key. If you forget it, you cannot access your content anymore.

data.title: Step 5: Set Expiration
items: Choose your content retention period: delete after first access(kept for maximum 1 hour), 30 minutes, or 1 hour. These automatic deletion settings provide built-in privacy protection.
Consider who needs access and when. Delete-after-access works great for one-time sharing, while timed deletion is perfect for temporary collaboration.

data.title: Step 6: Create Your Drop
items: Click **'Create My Drop'** to encrypt and upload your content.
Your content is encrypted locally using AES-256-GCM before transmission. Our servers only receive encrypted data - we never see your original text.

data.title: Step 7: Share with Developers
items: Copy the generated drop key and share it through secure channels. Recipients can view your code with full syntax highlighting on any device or browser.
The code is decrypted locally in the recipient's browser, maintaining end-to-end encryption. They can easily copy the code or view it with line numbers for debugging.

sections.title: How to Access Shared Content
sections.description: Follow these simple steps to securely access any content shared through Clipposaurus using a drop key.

data.title: Step 1: Visit Clipposaurus
items: Go to **clipposaurus.com** in any modern browser. The access interface loads instantly without requiring any downloads, installations, or account registration.
You'll see the main interface with options for creating new drops or accessing existing content. Click on the **Open Drop**.

data.title: Step 2: Enter Drop Key
items: Type the drop key you received into the access field. Drop keys are human-friendly phrases like **apple-beer-ocean** that are easy to remember and share.
The system automatically validates the key format and checks availability. Invalid or expired keys are detected immediately with clear error messages.

data.title: Step 3: Retrieve Content
items: Click **Unlock Drop** to begin secure retrieval. The encrypted content is downloaded and decrypted locally in your browser using the drop key.
This client-side decryption ensures that our servers never see your original content. The process is lightning-fast, and your content appears instantly.

data.title: Step 4: View & Download
items: Content appears instantly with full formatting preserved. Text content maintains line breaks and code gets syntax highlighting
Use the copy button for text/code content. All actions respect the original creator's sharing preferences.

data.title: Step 5: Secure Cleanup
items: Content automatically deletes from servers if configured for 'delete-on-access'. This ensures maximum privacy for sensitive information sharing.
Your browser clears temporary data automatically. No traces of accessed content remain on the device unless explicitly saved by you.
